title: Building AI: Our Shared Enterprise
segmentation: I am really very gratified to receive this award and also to have the opportunity to give a non technical talk in a way that is a little different than my usual talks, but probably near and dear to my heart in a lot of ways.
So I'd like to start this talk by asking you to consider a question, which is why are you here?
And by that I don't mean why you're here listening to me in this room as opposed to down the Hall.
What I mean is you know why you're here in Toronto, which for many of you is hundreds or thousands of miles away from your home.

And if you think about that kind of question, that question is kind of fun because you realize that we're all here for essentially the same reasons we want to exchange your ideas, find out what's going on in the field that you haven't heard about, bounce ideas off other people, and then we're also passionately interested in artificial intelligence.
Now.
I'm very excited to see what AI looks like in 20 years.
I don't know whether it will have, you know, a super Siri that can tell jokes and help me around the house and all sorts of great things like that.
Or maybe something that's less useful around the house, but more strategic in nature can help me answer big questions and help us find the cure to cancer and so forth.
Whatever it is, it's certainly exciting and I'm excited to see it happen.
I've been excited by all the great progress we've made in the last 20 years.
Some of it's very surprising.
But you know, as I've gotten older, I'm not.
I'm thinking maybe it's not happening fast enough, and so I really wanted, you know to.
It up and so this talks.
This sort of like.
Designed to consider how we get from here to there.
One of the things that we can do effectively to make it happen faster.
And I think one of the most important things that we can do is to share our work better and faster.
So this I'm going to talk about open science and the importance of collaboration.
How we share, why we share, how we can support sharing and can we do a better job.

I want to start by talking about this kind of a myth that's at least out there in the general public, and it's the myth that that science happens and breakthroughs happen by really, really smart people, kind of who sit in their room and think really hard about things and all of a sudden there's a breakthrough.
That's that's how it happens.
But in reality, I think we all recognize that doesn't happen like that at all, in fact.
I think almost all the developments that I thought were significant that I watched or participated in happened to the work of groups of people.
Evolving ideas overtime.
Sometimes that happens relatively rapidly if everyone is excited about a new thing, but there's always, you know, almost everything I've seen.
There's a bunch of people in.
Soft, and if you think about this question, how did the web come about?
I think that illustrates it.

He also named the Thing that we use today, the World Wide Web.

'cause often we have to fight to remove these barriers, so that's one of my goals.
